In 12-step meetings, at the beginning and end of every meeting, the "Serenity Prayer" is often spoken in unicen. However, Covid-19 has effectively mandated the moving of these face-to-face meetings to the phone. There, for whatever reason, it is impossible for the group to speak this prayer in unicen.

I find this phenomenon nearly intolerably discordant and have taken to turning the volume down super low so that I barely hear it, or even turn the volume off entirely until I think the prayer is done. It doesn't matter if I'm participating with everyone else or not, it's like fingernails on a chalkboard to me......

After watching the above video, the question is, given that the telephone is not something "mother nature created" is that why all these people find it impossible to say the prayer together even though in-person, once the rocky beginning has commenced, everyone quickly can, apparently effortlessly, say this all together regardless of how many people are in the room?

Additionally, why do I find listening to this so intolerable and others can seem to participate despite being unable to be in-sync? I've actually never talked about this to anyone. I don't even know if its uncomfortable for others at all, or they find a way to soldier through it (and I'm a wimp), or if its hard for them, just not as hard as it seems to be for me. (I did make a concerted effort for several months of several meetings per week to just endure it, but it never got any better......and I finally gave up trying. It isn't painful, but it is nearly so.....).

There is one documentary I saw on Ceaușescu, the Romanian communist leader pre 1989 that mentioned an interesting example of synchronicity: Applause.

When a crowd is clapping, if you listen closely you can hear two distinct forces in play: the crowd tends toward a comfortable, synchronized average speed with everyone clapping the same speed, but also enthusiastic individuals tend to want to clap faster than the average. So natural applause tends to synchronize and desynchronize in waves, resulting in what you're probably used to hearing.

Conversely, crowds at Ceaușescu's speeches didn't have that latter component - nobody was enthusiastic about his policies, but they were clapping because not clapping might get them labelled as an enemy of the state, which was not conducive to long term survival. So that applause syncs up quite quickly and doesn't deviate.

The documentary played a couple of examples of recorded applause from these speeches, and it sounds....odd. Hollow, alien....too perfect. Like something you would get if you took the audio of 1 person clapping and just layered it a thousand times over.

I like the example of the audience in Budapest. I'm Hungarian, this type of clapping is called the "iron clap" (true to word translation), it is done when an audience tries to express that they especially liked something. It can go on for a long time, synchronising, falling apart, synchronising again... When I first learned that people in other countries don't do this I was surprised. It's a custom here, so I would've never considered this being a random thing, but it is true. No one sets the rhythm, everyone just starts picking up the same thing after a while.

Hi Derek. Nice Video. I didn't know Prof. Steven Strogatz and I was really well impressed by him. He really is a great communicator and he I dare to say he was the soul of this video (not belitting your amazing work).
I already follow your channel since many years but I usually don't leave much feedback, but I had a lot to praise. It's also interesting to see how the quality developed over the years, congratulations.
A thought about this video though: to me, this tendency of synchronization of elements in a connected system doesn't seem that surprising, from a point of view of minimization of energy principle, so it felt a bit sensationalism (maybe a strong word for this, sorry) to sell it the way you did.

I know you have to reach different types of audiences, and you have to keep that dopamine of the viewer pumping during the video (especially in the first couple of minutes to lock their attention) but I would've sold it differently (I'm not trying to school you - it's merely personal opinion). I'm not sure if it's useful to bring up the second law of thermodynamics as a tendency for chaos opposed to the synchronization of some systems - maybe it was not your intention, but it tends to suggest that these systems are special and they can bend this law, or that there is a direct link between these two things. I thought it was confusing or unnecessary, except Prof. Steven Strogatz mentions it regarding the chemical reaction (but maybe it does makes sense and I am missing the point). I would've started by simply stating that we observe this, and that had to mean that there is some sort of interaction - so let's try to understand what mechanisms are behind this and if we can model it (as I write this, I realize I would not be a good show man).

On another note: I like the detail of the adding the sound to moons periodicity. It's really cool to realize that I have a hard time to identify a periodic motion by looking at the animation, but it's so easy to identify the period in terms of sound :)

So, i'm not gonna dwell on the politics of the implication, but something which has struck me in the past was watching a live recording of Tom Lehrer's performance in Denmark in the sixties or seventies. There is definitely a cultural component to this, because for whatever reason the audience had this tendency to synchronize their applause. It's a little unnerving almost, but after every song, they'd begin clapping chaotically (you know, as usual for an audience applauding) and within a few seconds, they'd all form into a single rhythm of near-perfect synchronous clapping.

I don't think it's something which was entirely intentional, because it seems that if it was, people would likely wait to begin clapping in sync, rather than beginning in chaos and falling into rhythm. I dunno. It was very interesting.

Hey guys at Veritasium, the clapping synchronization is not spontaneous, it's imitation from other concerts attended in the past since it's a long, long time tradition all around the globe. That is:
We, people that like to attend "classical" music concerts, have learned that when the concert has come to an end and the main performers go in and out from backstage for 2 or 3 times to bow and thank, then you can start to clap about 2 beats per second in order to ask for a reprise (because you are so fond of the performance that want more and it's also a way of telling the performers that they were awsome). It may sound impossible that everybody does this without instruction but it's not. Everybody gets it by intuition. It's like clapping in the same rythm as walking at a normal speed. So everybody is very used to it.
As an example, let's say the performers come out from backstage for the 3rd time, everyone that liked the performance a lot and want a reprise, clap louder as the performers had the gentleness to come again out of backstage and shortly after they start clapping around 2 beats per second. As you are not synchronized with everybody right away you try consciously to get synchronized with others by trying to clap at the beat of those claps that are already synchronized and therefore sound louder. Hence, how do the first bunch of synchronized claps happen? Normally people next to the stage that start clapping with that rythm try to get consciously synchronized and people surrounding follow making an expansion effect very fast as everybody tries consciously to be in the synchronized beat in order to let the performers know your intention. It can also happen that it comes from the back of the audience and people at the front then follow.
You can check this in all kind of classical videos and opera videos or attending a "classical" music performance.
On the contrary, this does not happen in pop music performances because when you want a reprise the tradition is to whistle, clap endlessly, shout loud, or simply shout "we want more!!" and again, trying consciously that your "one more song" shout gets synchronized with others or with the already synchronized shout coming from somewhere else in the audience.

Anyway, great video again from you guys! Congratulations and thank you so much for your amazing work!

Most analog color TVs used a phase-locked loop to synchronize the color oscillator. In that case, a circuit compares the incoming frequency to the oscillator frequency and adjusts the oscillator with a resulting control voltage.
However, some TV's were designed using "injection lock.' In this case, a certain amount of the incoming signal was coupled to the oscillator, enough to gradually bring it into synchronism with the broadcast signal, just like pendulums with enough coupling to each other to get that "phase change" from unlocked to locked. (In the case of a TV, the oscillator frequency was in the MHz range, and the signal was injected for a period of about 10 cycles, about 16000 times a second; so even if synchronization took a few thousand injections, it was practically instantaneous as far as the viewer was concerned.) This synchronization took place every time the viewer changed channels.

This is a GREAT video to show how "consensus" can be achieved through even the most minor coupling.

Imaging 100 pendulum clocks hung on a bar. Then they all agree on the exact millisecond, and this is taken as "it must be accurate because 100 random clocks agree".

How would this be distinguished from 100 atomic clocks that would also be fully synchronized, and would also agree?

The second the "agreement" is based on (even the weakest) coupled forces, it MUST be suspect. The stronger the coupling, the less certain the average answer is.

Dear Veritasium, One of your comments has given me a glimmer of insight into a physics problem that has perplexed me for years. It is the problem of corrugations forming on dirt roads and even on bitumen roads. I have experienced this on the Bruce Highway in Australia at Raglan. How is it that vehicles with different suspension characteristics can form regular corrugations which for several kilometres can have a constant wavelength?
Several years ago while tutoring an engineering student who was studying railways I learnt that the problem of corrugation occurs on rail lines as well. I was astonished. These rail lines carried coal trains mainly , the wagons of which are all very similar in characteristics.
It seems to me that the metronomes synchronise because they are physically connected at the same time. Is it possible that oscillators, such as vehicle suspensions, which are all different but pass over the road or rail at different times can become synchronised by passing over the road or rail sequentially in time? A new road or rail is dead flat, let's assume. Then, just as the metronomes synchronise in phase with the majority of the metronomes at the start, the wavelength in the road or rail is that of the most common wavelength of the initial vehicles and this is gradually impressed upon the road or rail.
I happily confess that my knowledge of this cyclic behaviour is limited. Perhaps someone else can enlighten me.

I think i've had the 'coupling' experience from running. Taking the 4-day Machu Picchu hike, I wondered where the sherpas went when they broke camp and got ahead of us every day. I was in sturdy hiking bootsd and maybe 10kg in my backpack. I'm not a runner, but I followed them for an hour on the goat trails either side of the main trail, jumping from rock to rock when the soil gave way to trickier ground, and following in their footsteps. Sometimes the lead would drop to the back and I'd be second to last. I have previously described it as their energy affecting me - slipstreaming, in a way. The new coronavirus epidemic that originated in Wuhan has spread to all provinces in China, as well as other Asia Pacific regions, North America, and Europe. Because the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) routinely covered up past epidemics, it is widely suspected that the true scale of the outbreak is significantly worse than officially reported. This leaves many people living in China helpless as the epidemic continues to worsen.

Falun Dafa practitioners outside China have also been looking for ways to offer help from a spiritual perspective. After the CCP began to suppress Falun Dafa in July 1999, practitioners saw that many people who stood up for justice and supported or protected practitioners often described miracles, including recovering from incurable illnesses, surviving otherwise fatal accidents, and resolving deep family conflicts. For many years, practitioners around the world have called people in China, suggesting that reciting the phrases “Falun Dafa is good” and “Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance is good” would bring blessings.

A deputy director of a district publicity department (formerly the propaganda department) in Beijing recently received such a phone call from a practitioner. Despite an initial misunderstanding, he began to reflect and eventually thanked the practitioner for the advice.

Disaster Caused by the CCP
The officer was first annoyed by the call. “We’re facing a national disaster right now, and you’re asking me to quit the CCP? Why?” he asked impatiently.

“These two are actually connected,” the practitioner replied gently. “Let me explain why.

“Wuhan Mayor Zhou Xianwang said on TV that he didn’t disclose the information in time because he wasn’t authorized to do so. This shows that it’s a systemic problem of the Party covering it up.

“After the illness was reported in early December, the government kept the public in the dark because they wanted to ‘maintain stability’ and prevent a panic. In the end, they lost control of the outbreak and caused an even bigger panic.

“SARS was handled in the same way. For months, the government covered it up and even attacked people who disclosed the information. You know very well what happened after that.

“Today, history is repeating itself,” the practitioner said. Drawing historical parallels with the Roman Empire’s persecution of Christians and subsequent plagues that killed about two-thirds of its population, she described the CCP’s brutality in its persecution of Falun Gong and spreading of propaganda to incite hatred.

“Heaven sees this clearly, so in your heart you have to undo the vow you made to give your life to the Party, in order to avoid paying for its crimes when it’s eventually held accountable,” she suggested.

The officer’s tone softened and acknowledged the practitioner’s reasoning. He listened quietly and said he was not involved in the persecution of Falun Gong.

Your opening statement makes zero sense in the any law of physics.

Let's actually look at the 2nd law of thermodynamics: The second law of thermodynamics establishes the concept of entropy as a physical property of a thermodynamic system.

entropy - (thermodynamics) a thermodynamic quantity representing the amount of energy in a system that is no longer available for doing mechanical work; "entropy increases as matter and energy in the universe degrade to an ultimate state of inert uniformity"

What you might be confusing this with is:
entropy - (communication theory) a numerical measure of the uncertainty of an outcome; "the signal contained thousands of bits of information"

or even:

(computing) theory)entropy - A measure of the disorder of a system. Systems tend to go from a state of order (low entropy) to a state of maximum disorder. (high entropy)

Please correct the video as you've mistaken theories for actual laws of thermodynamics.

19:19 welcome to field of computer simulations (also games) and AI. There's an inherent disconnect between designing requirements, the outcomes you want to get, and designing rules and orchestrating quantities of a system that is supposed to properly react and give you those outcomes. And it goes even more meta as in most cases you need many systems to interact with each other, so each system becomes a higher level entity of this next level of interaction. But because the higher level of interaction boils down to affecting the lowest level entities (unless you artificially abstracted them), systems tested in isolation can end up behaving vastily different than when they are interacting with each other.

AAHHHHHH! That's not what the 2nd law states!!! Disorder =/= thermodynamic equilibrium.
The 2nd law defines the concept of entropy which is basically a measurement of how close a system is to thermodynamic equilibrium. The higher the entropy, the closer the system is to being unable to perform thermodynamic work, basically not being able to do anything. The lower the entropy, the more work that can be done. If entropy remains constant then the process performing work is perfectly reversible.

This won't be read likely, but I'll say it anyways....real quick, the clapping audience is a misinterpretation of classical music performances/etiquette. That audience didn't get caught into some weird thing where they all mindlessly synchronized and no one knew why. Instead, a small group started the rhythmic clap, others heard it at took it up as a group...and the reason is that they want an Encore. This is how a classical audience calls for an encore (normally...on occasion someone will yell "encore" like in movies, but that's more likely in a concert with vocalists or Opera. An orchestral group...this is how the audience calls for Encore).

(Somewhat) interesting fact: this phenomenon is actually used in integrated circuit oscillators to obtain more stable, less noisy signals. Often two or more oscillators are "coupled" together, lowering the overall "phase  noise" (small unwanted frequency variations in the output signal). This is very important for modern applications: less phase noise allows for higher bitrates, or, in the case of radars, better object detection.

About Complexity. Leonard Susskind is doing research into how black holes exhibit complex systems phenomena, and he devised a way to talk about it that generalizes complexity theory as a whole...that systems can be described as moving from one state to another, and that the the transition from one state of a system to another state of a system is based on the minimum number of computations it takes to get from one to the other. He found that black holes reach thermal equilibrium orders upon orders upon orders of magnitude sooner then reaching Maximal complexity, when the system has cycled through all possible states, or rather cycles through the all computations.

So...what does the above mean? It means that Equilibirum...or complete homogeneity is not the final death state of a system....The maximal complexity is, which is the final state at which the exploration of all the different states of the system have been computated...This means that just like this synchronous behavior in the fluid, there can be, and in fact could be billions upon billions of oscillations of a black hole at thermal equilibrium to exit equilibrium into some heterogenous state, and return again... each time experiencing some other computational path as the system as a whole moves toward maximal complexity.

So what is the implication of that? If the universe is headed toward Heat Death...Entropy Death...then if the above is the case then simply put, entropy death isn't the final state of the universe...the maximal complexity of it would be...and that means we would experience, or have already experienced, every possible iteration and every possible computation of the universe there could ever be...it just takes zillions of years each time. What's that mean for life after death? This means that you live this exact same life a near infinite number of times, it just takes that much time for you to experience it again...and you've also experienced everyone else lives a zillion times...it just takes zillions of years. And consciousness? If you experience everyone's life over and over and your own over and over, each time slightly different or even the same...then what is conscious really but a concentrated perspective of an overall macroscale perspective that you experience eventually in a zillion years?

The implications for Susskind's theory are grave and interesting enough to make a video on. If you ever get the chance to read this, I suggest typing in Complexity and Gravity - Leonard Susskind's Lecture series.

Unsolved real world synchronisation: an electrical engineer was asked to set up a power line to a large field of oil pumpjacks (known as nodding donkeys). He estimated the electrical demand based on the number of pumpjacks multiplied by the average load on each pumpjack's electrical motor over a cycle of its movement. He assumed the pumpjacks would be unsynchronised and thus their individual peak demands would average out. You guessed it, somehow the pumpjacks synchronised and the power line was insufficient, creating a massive expense for a secondary power line. What was the mechanism for the synchronisation: hydraulic (pressure of oil in a common underground pool), vibrational (though the ground soil) or electrical (common power system)?

Nope. A lot of true facts - but - totally wrong about the people side sway source and its meaning. Would take me pages to relate, but the way we walk (people upright) is TIGHTLY related to conservation of energy. Human walking is insanely energy efficient ... at the speed which is dictated by the double pendulum legs swinging and the transfer of swing leg energy (deceleration must be prior to full swing) to the body (c of g) travel over the opposite side stance leg (vertical pendulum - Joe Pallooka punching bag). The two KINDS of pendulums MUST be in sync or else energy is LOST (debilitating and a major source of disability - usually unrecognized). So c of G does NOT lateralize over the stance leg (foot) but flies BETWEEN the width of the footsteps. UNLESS =>SLOWED<=.

With SLOWING, the flyby does not work and c of G requires wider flight curve to the support side (away from swing side). AVERAGE stride time (not related to the process but to the average SIZE & weight distribution of the people doing it - so it can vary) is 1.2 seconds. People leaving a movie (slowed by those ahead & limited narrow exit to # going through) spill a lot of popcorn as they get side bumped by slow walk side sway. Also tight (front to back) approximation has right foot end swing landing on person in front's Achilles tendon (OUCH!!!) just as that was about to swing. That too synchronizes steps in a cue.

Maintaining the pendulum is biologic goal #1. Using smaller arc of the pendulum is OK as long as the moving parts are still pendulum in type. It takes as much energy to SLOW a pendulum by a certain amount as it does to increase its speed by that same amount.

All gait (normal & abnormal) can be exactly modelled w 6 Fourier Harmonics (= 6 items which produce gait). Those harmonics are NEARLY in Fibonacci series (the radii of the harmonics are a blend of limb segment lengths vs center of mass of each segment as chicken drumstick shape has longer reach than the pendulum period would otherwise have.).

The resistances and pathology do NOT model well w Fourier but do w Laplacian methods (indicating that the human walking mechanism uses linear driving features but fails to external or abnormal internal exponential factors).

Also NOT mere coincidence that the distance of center of mass of the body to the hip center EQUALS ankle to forefoot length (locked ankle movement - even partial - eg. high heels ==> fanny has to rise & fall more to make it up. Other harmonics of unequal size cannot patch that). A lot more but, mmmmm.......

Synchronization of applause like demonstrated @9:55 is not a mechanical phenomenon. It isn't as "spontaneous" as Dr. Muller and his team make it out to be. It is an established social custom that audiences will choose to synchronize their applause as a show of particular delight and/or as an audible request for an encore. For an example of someone choosing to join in, notice the white-haired audience member near the middle of the frame. This person stops applauding for a second, then attempts to resume in rhythm with the rest of the audience.

The period of the claps can seem uncannily predetermined, but as most people's arms are of a relatively similar length... 🤷‍♂️

The idea that everything in nature tends towards chaos and randomness is completely belied by looking at nature. Just about everything in nature results in some sort of order. Put two different liquids in a test tube and leave it to stand and if their densities are even slightly different, they will separate from each other just due to gravity. Put muddy water in a glass and leave it to stand and it will separate into many layers. Throw water on the landscape (rain) and it flows downhill into rivers, lakes and the sea. It doesn't just stay randomly around the place. Pure randomness can only really occur when everything involved is identical and there are no force fields in effect.

There is an interesting distinction that was almost made at the end of the video. When I took Artificial Intelligence and Advanced Computing Strategies during my undergrad, we learned about a concept called Emergence. We learned that in an artificial neural network, it's not the neurons themselves that are important, it's the relationships (we called them weights) between them. In other words emergence is the idea that you cannot look at one entity as a unit, you must also understand the relationship between at least two entities. Ants, bees, neurons, people, planets, molecules, and a nearly infinite list of other things are comprised of certain properties that are the same in each entity, but many such properties are not expressed unless influenced by other entities of the same kind. The result of this expression is an 'emergent' property. The classic example is the idea that a single water molecule is not really considered "wet", but a couple billion are.

Order among chaos is an illusion seen only when we limit our observation to the lowest measure that will satisfy it. It disappears each time we open our eyes just a little wider. Sure, more order will appear, but the previous order we observed becomes part of a greater disorder once again. Hypothetically, if we were to eventually come to learn that all of human knowledge was wrong, then did we really ever know anything at all?

Which is why there is this tendency to synchronize in a seemingly chaotic universe. The end goal is to synchronize to such a stand-still, that gravity will then eventually pull everything back together to one singular point, and perhaps cause yet another Big Bang.

All nonlinear systems are necessarily different from the sum of their eigenstates, by definition. This is because the principle of superposition (the additivity of solutions) only holds in linear systems, which nonlinear systems are not. What makes a system nonlinear? What makes a function nonlinear? Why is f(x)=ax linear and f(x)=ax^2 nonlinear? Because in the second equation, the independent variable affects itself (x^2=x*x). Self interaction is the simplest kind of nonlinearity. The people affect the bridge the bridge affects the people - this is the same idea. You can read about monotonicity for more.

I was crossing a rope bridge one time during my time with the Army. As I was one of the last to cross, the bridge was already wildly swinging up and down even though only two to three of us were allowed on the bridge at once. I saw the guy in front of me had solid footing but was being lifted alarmingly high into the air despite being so short. Me, at six feet, I decided to take steps ONLY during the downward swing. This resulted in me looking like a Monty Python sketch, legs elevated high for each step and then coming down ridiculously far, but my upper torso smoothly remaining at the same elevation as I made my way across.

My question is this: Were my synchronized steps hurting the situation, helping, or doing nothing at all to affect the overall oscillation of the rope bridge?

Most of the matter in the universe flows mostly randomly. But when it happens to form a body which stays together, it will stay a body. That’s why we have planets.

There is no need for any universal law which favors order versus disorder. Common logic itself ensures that it is just a matter of time.

9:20 well he's wrong about water freezing. The whole cup of water definitely doesn't freeze all in an instant. Because when water freezes, it releases heat, its enthalpy of melting or freezing, and that serves as an impediment to the other water freezing. Just like boiling water. When you heat water on a stove, it doesn't just all vaporize together in a huge explosion when it gets to 212 degrees, because when some water does turn to steam, that cools the water around it by its enthalpy of vaporization.

Another reason things appear to be synchronized -- is confirmation bias. If you think things are sync'ed, you will notice the ones that are more than the ones that aren't.

Example: Popular Mechanics published a project where you put flashing christmas lights in a box behind a translucent screen. When placed near a speaker, the lights appear to sync to the music (because your brain ignores the ones that aren't). In reality, there was no mechanism for the lights to sync to the music.

Another example of synchronisation is when a planet has a ring of debris. Any perturbation in the ring causes gravity gradients, slowly pulling surrounding matter in, as the gravity well gets deeper and deeper as matter is accumulated, it pulls more and more from farther away, in. Eventually a new moon forms, clearing the orbital path of remaining debris.
The reason Saturn still has rings is because there are shepherd moons between rings that help stabilise them, plus the rings are replenished with dust and particles ejected from some of the moons within the rings' orbits.

The ending about how a system is not a sum of its parts―that a system at a macro level has more properties than the elements that it's built of at a micro level―is in my opinion the phenomenon in science that is least emphasised and hardly brought up.

Yet this phenomenon, which is called "emergence", is the most interesting and important property of our reality.

It's the reason why an enormous collection of H₂O (water) molecules can be a liquid, but why a collection of Ne (neon) atoms form a gas, even though they weigh the same at the atomic scale. Or why a right mix of sand and air molecules can make you literally swim in sand (YouTuber Mark Rober has a video on this). Or why conciousness can form from chemical reactions. Or why a direction of time only make sense when observing the processes of a vast collection of atomic particles.

Emergence extends the limit of what is physically possible, if you only consider the properties the isolated elements of a system have.

I think it's a topic that's definitely worth exploring.

You can't figure out the properties of the whole from the parts. I work with programming computers, this fact is amazing. The property of the parts are so simple, yet, you see all this complexity on your screen.
The magic is exactly creating layers so this complexity can appear. Each layer has its own rules and is studied separated, and when they interact, emergent behavior can appear. Entire fields were created to actually try to stop it from happening, but in the end, we realized that there's not way in complex dynamic systems, you have to embrace it.
What you can do is learn how properties of some part affect the whole, and how the whole affect the parts, you can't break them, simulation is a better tool to understanding, than top-down break, you do bottom-up simulation of behavior.
Its a lot more experimentation than design.
Going about simulating the Universe is lot more useful than going for trying to find its smallest constituents and then reverse engineer the complex behavior from the simple, as you can't do that, take the Game Of LIfe , for example, the rules are so simple, yet you can't derive the slider from them, you have to simulate.
That's the frontier of the Physics we are at, just simulating and observe, don't go isolating things.

This was a really nice video! As an electrical chip design engineer, I see the same phenomenon when designing electrical oscillators. Two different oscillators might work just fine on their own, but when putting them together on the same chip, you can observe both oscillators influencing each other and pulling each other out of sync. This can significantly disrupt the performance of the circuit, so it's important to place both oscillators far enough apart on the chip and simulate the coupling behavior happening between them. So fascinating to see a fundamental law of nature appear in the difference fields of science!

We had such a vibration issue once in a steel structure. FEA showed that we had a minimum Eigenfrequenz (not German, that is the word!) of just below 2Hz.
We looked closer and saw, that this frequency was in just one beam, which was connected to a rotating machine. But that machine was running at a frequency that was a multiple of that 2Hz (i recall it was 12Hz). This caused the whole platform to be vibrating, you could hardly stand on it and the bolts tended to get lose.
So we did two things: installed some dampeners, and changed that one beam to a larger one, which increased the Eigenfrequency. You could stil feel that the machine was running, but not way as much as before.

You missunderstand the second law of thermodynamics.
The way you mentioned it does only apply to quasi-closed systems. This is because the law was adapted first to engineering. Where you can make a change to a system, isolate the system and then approximate it as a closed system.
This does not apply to the universe. Because the universe is by definition a true closed system. So it has to have always been in thermodynamic equilibrium.
The idea of the heat death violates physics on a very basic level.

A system that has found thermodynamic equilibrium is not chaotic. It is cyclical. It may be complex. But it will still be cyclical.
Saturn can be viewed as a localized equilibrium. The more influential/stronger the laws that govern the system the more structured it will look like.
Thermodynamic equilibrium is a balance between entropy and the forces of nature.

Anyway, our universe mus be going trough infinite cycles expansion and contractions. Otherwise the big bang model has to be wrong. Since you can't create a lack of thermodynamic equilibrium in a true closed system.

Give us more on complex systems!

One nagging concern I have whenever I think of complex systems and chaos theory is that - while trained as an economist with my own professional experience of the chaotic nature of the so-called "business cycle" - I can't help but wonder about the claims made in respect to our (inevitably limited) ability to understand and, especially, predict the behaviour of other complex systems.

Near the end, this video names a few examples, but I always find myself wondering about the implications of complex systems/chaos theory for the biggest public policy issue of the day: climate change.

I especially wonder about the implications of having a complex (but generally rapidly evolving) human society sub-system embedded within an even more complex planetary system in which (generally slower-evolving) natural ecosystems also react to (very slow-evolving) planetary/orbital subsystems that are the focus of the "3-body problem" that first awoke us (former) scientific determinists to the frustrations of chaos theory...

In short, I'm not sure how seriously to take the oft-repeated claims to the effect that "if we don't constrain ambient CO2 emissions to X ppm by date Y, bad things Z1 to Zn will happen". An honest assessment of what realistically can and cannot be predicted against the chaotic backdrop of the complex planetary climate system and its interconnections with also-complex human and (other) natural ecological system as well as with orbital systems strikes me as a potentially very enlightening subject for a future Veritasium video...

So it is a cultural thing for us I guess.

about the clapping in Budapest - that's a thing we do at about every show, it's called vastaps ("iron clapping"), it's not spontaneous. but great video, absolutely fascinating! :)

That clapping in the theater in Budapest is not synchronization entirely. People consciously want to create that effect because it is usually required. It even has it's own name (behind the iron curtain) "iron-claps". It shows an even higher level of appreciation than regular clapping, and standing ovation is the last stage. Maybe the first time it ever happened it could've been that phenomena, but more likely it was a remanence of the communist era where it could come from an ideological demand that nobody were allowed to get out of line. Communist politicians were required to be appreciated like that. If you didn't clap you could get a middle of the night visit and you were off to the gulag in a back of a black car... Luckily today it is only required in the theaters and it is not mandatory.
